content: The Battle of Coral Sea did not put an end to the Japanese expansion in the Pacific, but it was a major turning point in the war. It was the first naval battle that the Japanese had not won, and it forced them to modify their strategy going forward. While the Japanese did not abandon their goal of expanding their empire in the Pacific, the battle had lasting effects on their military capabilities and their ability to project their naval power. The Japanese were no longer able to rely solely on their carrier fleet as a means of achieving victory, and they shifted towards a defensive strategy that was focused on protecting their own territories and carriers. Ultimately, the Battle of Coral Sea was a significant Allied victory that helped to turn the tide of the war in their favor.
